content.description: Shavasana is a resting pose practiced at the end of yoga sessions to promote deep relaxation.
content.benefits: It calms the nervous system, reduces stress, and helps integrate the benefits of the practice.
content.contraindications: People with lower back discomfort may need support under the knees.
content.practice_tips: Lie flat on your back with arms relaxed and eyes closed. Focus on natural breathing.

content.description: Bhujangasana is a gentle backbend that strengthens the spine and opens the chest.
content.benefits: Improves spinal flexibility and may help relieve mild back stiffness.
content.contraindications: Avoid deep practice during pregnancy or recent abdominal surgery.
content.practice_tips: Keep elbows slightly bent and avoid locking the lower back.

content.description: A foundational pose that forms an inverted V-shape with the body.
content.benefits: Strengthens the arms and legs while gently stretching the spine.
content.contraindications: People with wrist pain or high blood pressure should modify the pose.
content.practice_tips: Distribute weight evenly through hands and feet, keeping the neck relaxed.

content.description: Pranayama involves controlled breathing techniques used to regulate energy and calm the mind.
content.benefits: May improve focus, reduce stress, and enhance lung awareness.
content.contraindications: Certain techniques should be avoided by individuals with respiratory or cardiac conditions.
content.practice_tips: Practice slowly and gently, preferably under guidance if you are new.
